subject: RE: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... com.funnyfarm.toplevel.deeper.deeperstill.getondown.WeAreFinallyTher ...  ... Oh, OK. The above didn t read that way for me. ... Once, yes. I would
messageBody:
Jim Dixon wrote:
>>>>> Look at the bytecode. Whenever you call
>>>>>
com.funnyfarm.toplevel.deeper.deeperstill.getondown.WeAreFinallyTher
>>>>> e,
>>>>> it's in the bytecode, each and every character.

<snip/>

>> Did you take a look at the document? It seems actually to *specify*
>> that the method name *is not* encoded every where the method is
>> called. To me, this argument carries some weight...

> Of course.

> All names used are in the constant pool. The index is an index into
> the constant pool.

Oh, OK. The above didn't read that way for me.

> If you are referring to something not within the
> compilation unit, the name must be fetched and examined byte by byte.

Once, yes. I would be surprised if the modern JVM did this again and
again.

> Interpretation cannot be avoided if you use interfaces, abstraction,
> and operations like instanceof.

I'd think that C++ does provide the same features, doesn't it? Would you
say it's an interpreted language?

Confused, Ilja
